intro: Smilax corbularia subsp. synandra, commonly known as the Southern arrowwood, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Aristolochiaceae and is characterized by its stout, thorny stems and opposite, simple, ovate leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in umbels, followed by red, berry-like fruits. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and thickets. Its botanical features make it an important component of the understory vegetation in its native habitat.
